reviewText: You'll need thicker glasses than Super Granny to be able to play these games since the newest one's resolution is locked at 800x600, with the older ones being even lower.  The levels are platform and ladder puzzles where you rescue barely visible cats and collect microscopic ribbons.  You can dig holes, climb ladders and fall off platforms, but can't jump.  Not that any of this matters since, like Super Granny, you can't see a damn thing.

reviewText: I played Super Granny back when I was a child. This game is (to me) is mostly nostalgia, being why I bought it. But now onto why I was fond of this series from the beginning:\n-It is very original, and is more of a lol" than a "chessy"\n-The level design is unique
date: and every level is different (some require some thinking
recommended: some are just "run and gun" with a frying pan or something similar\n-In the game's menu (all titles in this collection have this) is a level designer
hoursPlayed: the same used by the developer who was in charge building these unique levels (each title has at least 120 levels)\n-This "Level Editor" offers you the exact same functions the developer had; no disadvantages\n-It can be fun and slightly addicting (what I do is play a number of levels of one title
voteText: then move on to the next title and so on\n\nI hope this review was helpful to an extent
helpfulPercent: and I learned yesterday (if I recall correctly) that the company that made this franchise is defunct and has been since 2012 which means this is "as is" and "will be". I like this franchise."

reviewText: Blatant Lode Runner clones done in a casual-gamer style that would make many run away from them. Yet, there's some good old school gameplay to be found in these, and with hundreds of stages they aren't a quick beat. Plus, it has freaking kitties. Kitties. How can you not like kitties, you heathen?
